question: A very preterm baby on 30mL/kg of enteral feeding, using an infant feeding formula, developed sudden severe abdominal distension with visible bowel loops on day 6 of life. The baby also showed temperature instability and lethargy. X-ray of the abdomen showed poal venous gas. The staging of NEC is?
exp: The given clinical scenario indicates a diagnosis of NEC. Salient clinical features helping to identify the stage of NEC are: Stage Feature 1a - Occult blood positive in stool 1b - Fresh blood in stool 2a - Abd X ray shows 'pneumatosis intestinalis' 2b- X ray shows Poal venous gas 3a - Peritonitis 3b - Pneumoperitoneum

question: Indication for surgery in Necrotizing Enterocolitis is?
exp: Pneumoperitoneum -NEC stage 3b- intestinal perforation occurs. Treatment includes suppoive care along with surgery. Modified Bell's Staging Criteria:
opa: Pneumatosis intestinalis- Stage IIA of NEC
opc: Poal Vein gas- Stage IIB of NEC
